subject: Re: [junit] testing private methods
msgSnippet: ... While I agree in principle, default access methods are the ones that bug me.  I prefer to keep my tests in a separate hierarchy, and because of this I
messageBody:
> I use JUnit not only as a testing tool, but also as a design tool. If I
> can't test something, the tool is telling me something about my design.
> I think that's a feature.

While I agree in principle, default access methods are the ones that bug
me. I prefer to keep my tests in a separate hierarchy, and because of this
I can't test methods with default access. This means I'm either forced to
make things that would normally have package scope "public", which is a bad
solution, or put my tests in the package, which I don't like either. This
is why this notion is interesting to me.

Take care,
Dale
--
Dale E. Martin, Clifton Labs, Inc.
